Award.AwardTitle: EMSW21-MCTP Notre Dame Honors Mathematics Program and the Seminar for Undergraduate Mathematical Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a five year plan to expand and intensify the Notre Dame Honors Mathematics Program together with SUMR. It aims for a sharp increase in the number of students pursuing graduate work in the Mathematical Sciences. It also aims to increase the number of minority students majoring in Mathematics at Notre Dame and taking higher level Mathematics courses. It includes funds for 2 postdocs, 3 graduate students, 37 scholarships for undergraduates and summer funds for 12 undergraduates each year.

Intellectual Merit:
This is a plan to train Mathematics undergraduates at a very high standard. It continues and broadens the tradition established by the SUMR program. It seeks to attract 8-10 undergraduate students per year into a career of research in one of the mathematical sciences. It expects to make these undergraduates attractive to the country's top graduate programs.

Broader Impacts:
This plan aims to replenish and broaden this nation's mathematical talent base. It will draw significant numbers of women into Mathematics, just as SUMR has done. It seeks to increase the number of Latinos and other minorities choosing a career in the mathematical sciences. In short, several constituencies traditionally served by Notre Dame have been historically somewhat hesitant in their engagement with the scientific tasks of our country. This plan contributes to redressing that deficiency and so deepens our society's commitment to its research mission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to make a significant expansion of a  program at Notre Dame called the Seminar for Undergraduate Mathematical Research (SUMR). 

    This expansion effort was outstandingly successful. In the years prior to the grant, SUMR would train an average of 2.5 undergraduate students per year for subsequent work in a strong Ph.D. program in one of the Mathematical Sciences.  Since this grant, SUMR has been expanded so that on average about 5.5 undergraduate students per year are pursuing a Ph.D. in some Matheamatical Program.

      SUMR has also maintained a very high standard by the measure of National and International Fellowships. Among the 93 SUMR students whose year of graduation is 2014 or earlier, there have been 46 winners of National or International Fellowships, and more are expected among the classs of 2014.

     SUMR graduates have been winners of the following fellowships:

NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, NDSEG Fellowship, Goldwater Scholarship, Churchill Scholarship, Sloan Fellowship, NSF Postdoc Fellowship, Lucent Fellowship, Shaefer prize, Marshall Scholarship, National Physical Sciences Consortium Fellowship, Fulbright Scholarship.

The expansion involved hiring post-docs whose focus would be principally on work with highly talented undergraduates, and also running extra seminars for the SUMR students. We also gave scholarships to SUMR students to encourage them to commit to a career of research. We also had summer programs for students to engage in research.
